snippet.textDisplay: Shame on all the leaders who boycotted the Opening Ceremony. Thomas Bach IOC chief said it right, the rest of the world violated UN truce resolution 48/11 that the Olympic Games should not be used politically and even allows for a cease fire in war times. The western countries who boycotted have violated that resolution and should be reprimanded. Worse even, the Olympic truce guarantees the safety of all athletes when travelling to conflicting countries. Not only did boycotting countries violated the resolution, they even put their athletes in danger by sending them to the Olympics while boycotting it, luckily China is not vengeful!

snippet.textDisplay: The one thing that whole world knows about china is that the corona virus and yellow dust is from china. Just admit it, instead stealing other country's cultural heritage.

snippet.textDisplay: Omicron and Delta for example are covid versions that are not from China. Most deaths in the west due to covid have been caused by the Delta. China is actually desperately wanting to keep the Delta version out of their country. Research has shown that the Wuhan virus was also a mutation, and the original virus, although in a mild less contagious and less deadly form, was already roaming in Europe, North America and Australia at the beginning of 2019. It just so happens China holds the international Military games in November 2019, coincidence? So what happened is that it just mutated in China and broke out on a large scale due to the dense and large population of china. When this information became known the researchers became awfully silent, and nobody is talking about it, and politicians were trying to deflect that fact and accused China of a lab leak, which U.N. inspections found nothing of such sort. So where do we put the blame game then? Do you also blame countries who have earthquakes, vulcano erruptions or other natural disasters? Virus outbreaks are natural disasters and its no use to blame a particular country.

snippet.textDisplay: Being a bigger country does not have the right to take away one country's deep and traditional culture. Even though others might think the difference between China's culture and Korea's culture is minor, each country has been preserving its own unique culture which is clearly different from other countries. For Korea, 'Kimchi' has been their own unique traditional food that they have been making and consuming from the ancient past, and 'Hanbok' was the type of clothing that Koreans have been wearing since the ancient dynasties. Though China claimed that introducing Korean culture was just for the Korean Chinese living in China, introducing this culture by portraying the general Korean traditional lifestyle as if it is 'part' of China's culture seems as if China is taking away every part of Korean culture and showing off to people as if the culture is theirs. This action is a big disrespect to one country's special culture and is regarding all the prolonged history of Korea and the traditional lifestyle Koreans have been keeping as if they were all copied from China's cultures. To Koreans, it is the same as China claiming America's culture as if it is 'part' of their culture as there are Chinese Americans in China. Please don't differentiate each country's culture and regard it as petty based on how large the country is. Koreans are proud of their culture, and they do not want to get this taken away in any way or form. If China wanted to introduce this tradition, they should have introduced the video and hanbok as 'Korean culture. Also, how is the popularity of Kpop and Kdramas, movies related to this issue? The popularity was gained by worldwide people's positive interest, and this is solely focused on China trying to justify their action of regarding Korean tradition as their 'piece' of the culture. (Hanfu is the copy of Hanbok. If you are curious about this fact, GOOGLE IT) (Kimchi is Korea's food, and the video that portrayed a family wearing hanbok, grabbing hands together portrays the EXACT culture of Korea).

snippet.textDisplay:
Koreans are very afraid of being known by the world that the Koreans are one of the 56 ethnic groups in China! When their national costume or culture is on the stage in China, Koreans don't see it as an honor, but seriously hurt their self-esteem. Because ancient Korea has always been a territory of China, its writing uses Chinese characters, and its culture and folk customs are also deeply influenced by China. Whether it is food, clothing, festivals, medicine, architecture, technology, it is partially or completely learned from China. Even the officials of the Joseon Dynasty were canonized and dismissed by Chinese monarchs!
How can Koreans, who consider themselves superior now, let the world know these historical facts?
